block.p: Tally Last Week in Connecticut, New Jersey and New York.

1. Judicial Nomination -- Vote on the confirmation of Thomas B. Griffith to the United States Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia Circuit, making him the sixth of President Bush's appellate court nominees to be approved under a Senate compromise on judicial candidates. Mr. Griffith was Senate legal counsel during the impeachment trial of President Bill Clinton before assuming his current post as general counsel at Brigham Young University. Approved 73 to 24, June 14.

2. Ethanol -- Vote on a measure that would require refiners to add eight billion gallons of ethanol, a corn-based fuel, each year to the gasoline supply by 2012. President Bush has said a new emphasis on biofuels, like ethanol, would contribute to a reduction in oil imports. Approved 70 to 26, June 15.

3. Renewable Fuels -- Vote on legislation that would require power companies to use more renewable fuels like wind and solar power to generate electricity. The White House and the House, where longtime oil industry allies have already produced a measure favoring traditional fossil fuels, oppose the utility requirements. Approved 52 to 48, June 16.
KEY: (A) Absent or did not vote; (P) Present.

1. Patriot Act -- Vote on a provision of the USA Patriot Act that makes it easier for federal investigators to review the records of libraries and bookstores on national security grounds. Critics of the provision, which was approved in the aftermath of the Sept. 11 attacks, say it was an excessive grant of authority to the F.B.I. and Justice Department that threatened privacy and fundamental constitutional rights. Proposal to block the provision was accepted 238 to 187, June 15.

2. United Nations -- Vote on legislation that would cut by half the dues paid by the United States to the United Nations unless the international organization drastically overhauled its structure. The bill, opposed by President Bush, would slash American dues to the international body by 50 percent starting in 2007 if the United Nations did not meet a list of 46 requirements, including greater financial transparency and independent oversight. Approved 221 to 184, June 17.
KEY: (A) Absent or did not vote; (P) Present.
Tally Last Week in Connecticut, New Jersey and New York.

1. Judicial Nomination -- Vote on the confirmation of Thomas B. Griffith to the United States Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia Circuit, making him the sixth of President Bush's appellate court nominees to be approved under a Senate compromise on judicial candidates. Mr. Griffith was Senate legal counsel during the impeachment trial of President Bill Clinton before assuming his current post as general counsel at Brigham Young University. Approved 73 to 24, June 14.

2. Ethanol -- Vote on a measure that would require refiners to add eight billion gallons of ethanol, a corn-based fuel, each year to the gasoline supply by 2012. President Bush has said a new emphasis on biofuels, like ethanol, would contribute to a reduction in oil imports. Approved 70 to 26, June 15.

3. Renewable Fuels -- Vote on legislation that would require power companies to use more renewable fuels like wind and solar power to generate electricity. The White House and the House, where longtime oil industry allies have already produced a measure favoring traditional fossil fuels, oppose the utility requirements. Approved 52 to 48, June 16.
KEY: (A) Absent or did not vote; (P) Present.

1. Patriot Act -- Vote on a provision of the USA Patriot Act that makes it easier for federal investigators to review the records of libraries and bookstores on national security grounds. Critics of the provision, which was approved in the aftermath of the Sept. 11 attacks, say it was an excessive grant of authority to the F.B.I. and Justice Department that threatened privacy and fundamental constitutional rights. Proposal to block the provision was accepted 238 to 187, June 15.

2. United Nations -- Vote on legislation that would cut by half the dues paid by the United States to the United Nations unless the international organization drastically overhauled its structure. The bill, opposed by President Bush, would slash American dues to the international body by 50 percent starting in 2007 if the United Nations did not meet a list of 46 requirements, including greater financial transparency and independent oversight. Approved 221 to 184, June 17.
KEY: (A) Absent or did not vote; (P) Present.

Correction: June 21, 2005, Tuesday The Votes in Congress chart on Sunday referred imprecisely in some copies to a House vote on an amendment to the USA Patriot Act that would have made it easier for federal investigators to review the records of libraries and bookstores on national security grounds. Representatives were voting on a measure to block the amendment -- not on the amendment itself, although it was effectively rejected. The measure passed, 238 to 187.

The Votes in Congress chart on Sunday referred imprecisely in some copies to a House vote on an amendment to the USA Patriot Act that would have made it easier for federal investigators to review the records of libraries and bookstores on national security grounds. Representatives were voting on a measure to block the amendment -- not on the amendment itself, although it was effectively rejected. The measure passed, 238 to 187.
